items.title: py-mini-racer on Windows
items.body:
Hi,
I wanted to install py-mini-racer on windows, but although they should exist according to the readme I couldn't find any binary files anywhere. Did I miss something? Do they just not exist yet?

Anyway, so the pip wheel did contain the sources... and I tried to compile that...
which after 6 hours or so of googling compiler settings and rewriting code to not use pthreads, have the right paths, figuring out static vs dynamic linking etc, did eventually work out.
Just for me to find out this morning, that all this work had already been done in the github version which just isn't on pip yet. (Feeling pretty stupid to not have checked that first.)

Ok, dropping the plan of forking the repo and polishing up my rather dirty fixes and back to compiling. Actually it went pretty smooth this time, figured out that missing build_ext option was a problem of not updating setuptools, mklink seems to require elevated privilege in recent windows 10 version, but apart from that it just worked.

TLDR;
windows binaries or at least an updated source release would be great
(Oh and thanks to everyone who works/worked on this project - it's super usefull :)

items.title: Can you copy a context?
items.body:
### Steps to reproduce
```
ctx = py_mini_racer.MiniRacer()
ctx2 = deepcopy(ctx)  # or copy(ctx)
```

### Expected behavior
ctx2 is a copy of ctx

### Actual behavior
`ValueError: ctypes objects containing pointers cannot be pickled`

---
I'm sure it's a bit more difficult to copy a whole context than just expecting it to work, but I haven't found a way to do it. Am I doomed to having to create empty contexts or have I missed something?

items.title: Segmentation fault on ES6 Symbol evaluation
items.body:
### Steps to reproduce
Tested on both Mac + Ubuntu Linux:
```
from py_mini_racer import py_mini_racer
ctx = py_mini_racer.MiniRacer()
ctx.eval('Symbol.toPrimitive')
```

### Expected behavior
Python object representing an ES6 Symbol type should be returned.

### Actual behavior
Segmentation fault generated on Symbol evaluation.

Mac:
```
python3 -c "from py_mini_racer import py_mini_racer; py_mini_racer.MiniRacer().eval('Symbol.toPrimitive')"
Segmentation fault: 11
```
Linux:
```
python3 -c "from py_mini_racer import py_mini_racer; py_mini_racer.MiniRacer().eval('Symbol.toPrimitive')"
Segmentation fault (core dumped)
```

### System configuration
* Mac Mojave 10.14.3
* Ubuntu 18.04.2 LTS

**PyMiniRacer version**:
* py-mini-racer (0.1.18)

**Python version**:
* Mac: Python 3.7.2
* Linux: Python 3.6.7

items.title: Syntax error with imports
items.body:
### Steps to reproduce
I love the idea of using something like PyMiniRacer to do server-rendering of React components without needing to manage a Node server. But I'm stuck on the very first steps ... importing React. I'm not sure if this is a bug or a problem in my understanding. If so perhaps there is a missing step in the documentation?

I'm unable to do any JS imports (ES6 or ES5). Do I need to upgrade V8 or build it from source perhaps?

In virtual environment run `pip install py_mini_racer`, then:

items.title: Invoking a function
items.body:
### Steps to reproduce

Suppose I have the following code: 

```
code = """
function check() {
    return {
        create: function() {return "create"},
        update: function() {return "update"}
    };
}
"""

ctx = py_mini_racer.MiniRacer()
ctx.eval(code)

check = ctx.execute('check()')
```

Now `check` contains two java script functions:

```
{'create': <py_mini_racer.py_mini_racer.JSFunction at 0x7fe81400c128>,
 'update': <py_mini_racer.py_mini_racer.JSFunction at 0x7fe81448b4a8>}
```

How do I invoke them from python/PyMiniRacer? `ctx.execute(check['create'])` and `ctx.call(check['create']` don't seem to work

items.title: ImportError: No module named 'pip.req'
items.body:
### Steps to reproduce
pip install py-mini-racer

### Expected behavior
install !

### Actual behavior
setup.py", line 12, in <module>
        from pip.req import parse_requirements
    ImportError: No module named 'pip.req'

### System configuration
**Python version**:
python 3.5
pip 10.0.1 

### solution
Seems to be an incompatibility with new version of pip (>=10)
https://stackoverflow.com/a/49867265/1619521

so have to change 
`from pip.req import parse_requirements`
to
```
try: # for pip >= 10
    from pip._internal.req import parse_requirements
except ImportError: # for pip <= 9.0.3
    from pip.req import parse_requirements
```

items.title: Possible to load an external library?
items.body:
Hello,

My apologies if this is not the right place; I didn't see a mailing list and the main hit I get is the [intro blog post](https://blog.sqreen.io/embedding-javascript-into-python/) which didn't seem the best, either.

To try and keep it brief, there's [a desire](https://community.plot.ly/t/use-plotly-offline-to-save-chart-as-image-file/408) to export image files from `plotly` without having to go through their servers. The functionality exists in their library, but one has to open the `.html` in a browser to trigger the `downloadImage()` function.

Due to this, solutions are somewhat hokey, relying on `selenium` and `phantomjs` to fake a browser session and either screenshot the page or trigger the download. I'm wondering if `py_mini_racer` would allow for calling the `js` code directly without having to do this.

I'm a `python` noob, and even more so for `js`. I *think* what I'm asking is, "Can I do the equivalent of this with `py_mini_racer`"?
```
<head>
  <script src="https://cdn.plot.ly/plotly-latest.min.js"></script>
</head>
```

Then, I could do something [like this](https://plot.ly/javascript/getting-started/), replicating what would normally be inside of `<script>`:
```
ctx.eval("""
Plotly.plot( "div_name", [{
	x: [1, 2, 3, 4, 5],
	y: [1, 2, 4, 8, 16] }], {
	margin: { t: 0 } } );
"""
```

Am I understanding this library correctly?

items.title: Is it possible to invoke provided Python functions in the JS script?
Changes in libv8's builder.rb file since Oct 2016
items.body:
Hi,

Just a heads up -- I've updated a few things since you last touched your `v8_build.py`. Check out https://github.com/cowboyd/libv8/compare/d64aebf6c53b7402241b1c769299902ebe1a7bd3...master#diff-aec54aa0f7e48aa0b8c39b9d58825419 (important changes are in `builder.rb` and an additional patch to prevent debugging being included in macOS binaries)

items.title: Passing non-primitive objects
items.body: In V8 you can pass a C++ function into the JavaScript context, to use as a callback etc. It would be very useful if this can be exposed to MiniRacer. The current implementation of `call` relies on `json.dumps`, so a more sophisticated bridging method would be required.

items.title: Add a way to be more memory efficient
items.body:
The recommend way to use pyminiracer is:

```
>>> from py_mini_racer import py_mini_racer
>>> ctx = py_mini_racer.MiniRacer()
```

If we want to have several isolated contexts, the best way seems to create several contexts but it seems to dlopen the library each time a new context is created. Could pyminiracer dlopen the library only once in order to be more memory efficient while keeping the context isolated?

items.title: Performance question
items.body:
Hello,

We are using V8 to convert saved JS generated objects (dictionaries) with sensitive data to python objects, as it much faster than other ways we tried. Our dictionaries usually have at least 2000-3000 elements.

We tried different libraries to take benchmarks what are all based on different V8 versions. Your library is very easy to install and use, but it's 10 times slower than PyV8 in our case. Do you have some ideas how to improve this speed?

Here are bench results for your lib and PyV8 https://github.com/qistoph/pyv8 (what has best performance), we also tried v8eval (it has a little faster speed than you have) and  v8 cliff https://pypi.python.org/pypi/v8-cffi - this library has the same as PyV8 performance, but it returns all time strings (so no object conversion)

Here is code we used, with "a" variable as 2K elements JS dictionary. 

**PyV8**

``` python
import PyV8
ctxt = PyV8.JSContext()
ctxt.enter()
t = time.time()
ctxt.eval(a)
print(time.time() - t)
```

**Time Taken:** 0.0019199848175

**PyMiniRacer**

``` python
from py_mini_racer import py_mini_racer
ctx = py_mini_racer.MiniRacer()
t = time.time()
ctx.eval(a)
print(time.time()-t)
```

**Time Taken:** 0.0178089141846

The only difference in results, is that you returns python Dict, and PyV8 returns JSObject (what is like Python object).
### Expected behavior

Faster Speed
### Actual behavior

Slower speed :-)
### System configuration

**PyMiniRacer version**:
Latest one

**Python version**:
Python 2.7.12

```
   print 'Running: %s' % (' '.join(pipes.quote(x) for x in cmd))
                      ^

SyntaxError: invalid syntax
```
